content.body: you know,<details><legend> was more workable in IE than <details><dt><dd>, but unworkable in Firefox
I actually got <details><legend> working in IE (with a rather large chunk of Javascript) pretty reliably, except for CSS styling
though <legend> was still a bad idea
Lachy, you could prolly add a note that it's intentionally invalid
boo, minefield nightlies don't work on Tiger any more :(
i guess it would've been nice for the updater to refuse to do the update...
heycam: you're not the only one, although I'll be off my 10.4 machine in a few days
jwalden, yeah i guess everything's pushing me to buy snow leopard :/
snowkitty is cheap, if you have an intel system
and if you're already on 10.5
I'm a bit RAM-challenged lately so I kind of need a new machine anyway
i've got an old-ish mac mini (core duo 1.5ghz i think)
hopefully it takes well to SL
and i've heard that you can just install SL on to a blank hard disk without needing leopard
sees http://www.ebusiness-unibw.org/wiki/Rdfa4google
I wonder if they're aware that Google doesn't even parse application/xhtml+xml pages with an XML parser, never mind processing <!ENTITY definitions
(Actually that's just for their normal search results, I haven't tested how their Rich Snippets thing parses XHTML pages...)
using entities in curies is, I think, more indirection than I have ever seen to produce what is ultimately an opaque identifier string
heycam: make sure you have at least a gig of ram, "snowkitty" won't install on my old mac mini
It's not opaque, you can dereference http://purl.org/goodrelations/v1#hasOpeningHoursDayOfWeek to find out all about it (in a non-machine-readable format at least)
Oh, actually it does some kind of content negotiation so I get the non-machine-readable version, while the W3C Validator gets RDF
Hixie, yeah i've got 1.5GB
Hmm, I was wrong about how the Rich Snippets thing parses pages, it's seemingly not the same as used for search results etc
It's not the same as any proper HTML parser, or any proper XML parser, either

It seems to be kind of an error-correcting XML parser -

results in nested elements,

results in a closed element, α works (with no declared doctype), entities defined in doctypes are ignored
and it uses the same parser for text/html and application/xhtml+xml
how do you determine that it isn't the parser used for search results?
(just curious, i actually don't know if it is or not)
Hmm, actually I don't know
I assumed I'd tested it or something, but seemingly I haven't, so I could be wrong
I suppose I also assume Google wouldn't use something so unlike an HTML parser for something serious like search results
you also assumed that the rdfa processing would have some relationship to the rdfa spec
Sure, but that's an experimental new implementation with approximately zero users, vs a mature decade-old technology with a billion users
so I still cling to hope
can someone please explain to me why the server sorts this table differently if i view it chrome than if i view it in safari?:

nn
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-rdf-in-xhtml-tf/2009Sep/0183.html
hsivonen: IE "works" because it doesn't support XHTML, I guess?

I realize this might not be the correct channel to ask this, if there's a better channel to ask in please point me to it :). When trying to validate my html5 code at http://html5.validator.nu/ I'm getting "Text run is not in Unicode Normalization Form C." errors for my åäö:s When manually retyping them in the text field for the validator the error goes away. What encoding in my document should I be using to remove this errors?
eighty4: hmm... I think you should be using entities, over encoded characters

It's not the character set that is at fault, but the encoding of the character set. There are multiple ways to represent characters like å in Unicode. How you force NFC depends on what your editor is :)
eighty4: you can continue to use UTF-8. how did you create the content
hsivonen: coda using utf-8
eighty4: problem with coda then
eighty4, look for an option in your editor to save the document in UTF-8 with NFC normalisation.
gsnedders: shouldn't a web-dev editor be setup to work properly from the start?
>< stupid coda
eighty4, ideally, yes. Unfortunately, not always in practice
wonders why it's not using NFC
none of the encoding options say anything about nfc :/
eighty4: anything about precomposed vs. decomposed?
http://screencast.com/t/PlyND9jmqHT is the only related thing I can find
doesn't seem to be a forum for coda. Just an email address.
eighty4: did you copy and paste the text from the FInder by any chance?
hsivonen: from within coda
but I guess it could be an os x problem
eighty4: try filing a bug on Coda
eighty4: this is relatively easy to get wrong with Cocoa. Apple once shipped Preview.app with a bug like this
no apps seems to actually say what they use.
textmate does handle it ok. Guess it's a problem with coda then.
there. mail sent to the coda devs
Hixie: do you remember off hand how canvas tainting interacts with document.domain?
looks like it ignores document.domain
abarth, document.domain only affects few things
great
just want to make sure i'm fixing this the right way
the idea is to make document.domain not affect more than needed
oh, yeah, i'm definitely in favor of that
the current code in webkit was taking document.domain into account
(and also screwing up on data URLs)
so I'm fixing both bugs while i'm at it
abarth, ah, I think I filed a bug on that once
abarth, on WebKit that is
annevk42: well, it's about to get fixed :)
